Regional Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 41063  
June 2008  
 
 
 
Managing Water in Asia’s River Basins: Charting 
Progress and Facilitating Investment 
(Financed by the Japan Special Fund) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Water scarcity and deteriorating water quality are critical concerns to many countries in 
the Asia and Pacific region. Rapid population growth, urbanization, and underperformance of 
existing water assets are contributing to a significant shortfall in water services. The region’s 
fresh  water  resources─river  basins,  watersheds,  and  wetlands─are  already  in  peril  from 
pollution and fragmented management. Climate change will cause further impacts to these 
resources and add complexity and urgency to the challenge for better water management.  
 
2.  Adopted in 2001, of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Water for All policy fosters 
integrated water resources management (IWRM), as well as improvements in water service 
delivery. Across the region, ADB clients have adopted IWRM, and an increasing number of 
water loans are now prepared for river basins. In 2005-2006, one third of approved water 
technical assistance (TA) activities and one quarter of approved water loans were for river basin 
investments. Most of these investments involved the establishment or strengthening of a river 
basin organization (RBO) to facilitate IWRM.  
3.  By fostering IWRM in river basins, the Water for All policy underscores the need to shift 
from fragmented and sector-based project planning to a cross-sectoral process that is holistic 
and  inclusive.  IWRM,  a  long-term  process  that  needs  sustained  commitment  by  all 
stakeholders, seeks to realize investments in water resources development and management 
that have a “triple bottom line”, i.e., economic, social, and environmental benefits that result 
from an integrated approach. IWRM promotes coordinated development and management of 
water, land, and related resources to maximize economic benefits and social welfare equitably 
without compromising the sustainability of vital ecosystems.1  
4.  In March 2003, at the 3rd World Water Forum in Kyoto, Japan, ADB signed a letter of 
intent with the Water Resources Development Public Corporation of Japan (now the Japan 
Water Agency) and the ADB Institute to launch the Network of Asian River Basin Organizations 
(NARBO). NARBO aims to help introduce IWRM in river basins and to strengthen RBOs’ 
capacity and effectiveness in promoting IWRM and improving water governance. NARBO was 
formally  established  in  February  2004  with  its  own  charter  and  now  has  65  member 
organizations from 12 countries in the region. The NARBO chair is from Indonesia, and the vice-
chair is from Sri Lanka. NARBO’s secretariat comprises the Japan Water Agency, ADB, and the 
ADB Institute.  
 
5.  In March 2006, at the 4th World Water Forum in Mexico City, Mexico, ADB announced 
its Water Financing Program (WFP) for 2006-2010 to double water investments and achieve 
targeted outcomes through rural, urban, and basin water investments. WFP’s basin water target 
is to help introduce IWRM in 25 river basins.2 To achieve this target, ADB has developed a list 
of important IWRM elements and a generic road map to assess progress.  
 
6.  In 2006, NARBO’s 2nd General Meeting requested that ADB: (i) lead the introduction of 
RBO performance benchmarking and peer review; (ii) support capacity development in RBOs;

(iii)  chart  the  progress  of  IWRM  in  river  basins  in  the  region;  and  (iv)  facilitate  further 
investments in river basin projects to introduce IWRM, involving RBOs as facilitators.3  
 
7.  To date, progress in performance benchmarking and peer review has been encouraging, 
with ten RBOs volunteering to join the process, and four RBOs completing their peer review by 
2007.4 ADB has continued to support training programs and workshops for NARBO members, 
including one on water rights in May 2007. ADB has also consulted with the World Conservation 
Union (IUCN)5 in developing a regional TA project6 to chart IWRM progress in river basins in 
the region and in promoting further IWRM investments under NARBO. The TA design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
8.  Under WFP, ADB has committed to doubling its water investments during 2006-2010 to 
well over $2 billion per year. The overall target for ADB’s lending under WFP is $10 billion, of 
which  basin  water  investments  are  expected  to  contribute  approximately  25%.  Under  this 
scenario,  ADB  seeks  to  increase  basin  water  investments  under  WFP  to  
approximately $3 billion. To deliver the additional investments, ADB needs to expand its basin 
water  operations  with  long-term  IWRM  investment  programs  in  river  basins  that  include 
infrastructure, management reforms, and capacity development. Regional cooperation through 
the Asia-Pacific Water Forum (APWF) and NARBO is crucial to supporting these investment 
programs and will allow ADB to provide strategic assistance to its country programs.  
9.  Water  governance—how  people  and  their  institutions  work  together,  make  correct 
investment decisions, and implement them effectively—is key to delivering sustainable solutions 
to immediate problems. Therefore, stakeholder participation, local actions, and ownership are 
necessary building blocks for achieving IWRM in river basins. Stakeholders’ active and informed 
participation in planning and decision-making for integrated investment programs, including 
water  resources  allocation,  conflict  resolution,  and  trade-off  choices,  is  central  to  IWRM’s 
success.  The  independent  panel  reviewing  ADB’s  water  policy  implementation  in  2006 
reiterated the need for ADB to promote more river basin investment projects with stakeholder 
ownership of the IWRM process. 
10.  In the past decade, most countries in the region have already adopted national water 
policies that advocate IWRM in river basins. However, IWRM implementation is still at an early 
stage, and exchanging experience and analyzing lessons learned is an effective way to catalyze 
further  investments.  Through  NARBO,  it  is  now  possible  to  provide  quality  programs  for 
exchanging information and experience, and building capacity to help introduce IWRM in river 
basins. RBOs are crucial in facilitating IWRM introduction, including regulatory changes with 
stakeholder involvement, and preparation of further investments.

4  Performance benchmarking and peer reviews have to date been completed in the Citarum River Basin (Indonesia),

empowerment, and information.

11.  Working with NARBO partners and drawing on lessons learned from earlier projects 
across  the  region,  ADB  has  identified  four  challenges  to  encouraging  further  basin  water 
investments in the region that will be addressed through the proposed TA. First, RBOs’ capacity 
to prepare new IWRM investments must be strengthened. Increasingly, RBOs play a facilitating 
role in preparing new investment programs that are based on local knowledge and strong 
collaboration among a basin’s government and non-government stakeholders. To develop their 
capacity for this role, RBOs need assistance to develop road maps for long-term integrated 
IWRM  investment  programs. 7   Second,  RBOs  need  better  information  to  improve  their 
performance  in  adapting  IWRM  to  a  basin’s  changing  needs,  including  those  caused  by 
urbanization, decentralization, and climate change. Third, a systematic assessment of IWRM 
progress across the region is needed to learn lessons and identify requirements and good 
practices for further investments. Fourth, further capacity development programs for RBOs are 
necessary to improve their performance in delivering results.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The proposed TA aims to encourage further basin water investments under WFP and 
demonstrate good practices in introducing IWRM in river basins across the region. This will be 
achieved by: (i) enabling RBOs to prepare road maps for long-term integrated river basin 
investment programs, (ii) improving RBO’s technical knowledge to introduce IWRM and adapt to 
river  basins’  changing  needs,  (iii)  assessing  country  performance  and  good  practices  in 
introducing IWRM  in  river  basins,  and  (iv)  improving  RBOs’  performance  through  capacity 
development.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The proposed TA will have four components: (i) a project development facility, (ii) RBO 
knowledge  service,  (iii)  country  performance  assessments,  and  (iv)  RBO  performance 
improvement.  
 
14.  Project Development Facility. A road map advisory service (RAS), which will be piloted 
in five river basins across the region, will be developed to help RBOs in preparing road maps for 
long-term  integrated  river  basin  investment  programs.  The  five  pilot  river  basins  are  the 
Baitarani in India, Vu Gia-Thu Bon in Viet Nam, Bicol in the Philippines, Bengawan Solo in 
Indonesia, and the four Ps river basin area (Prek Preah, Prek Krieng, Prek Kampi, and Prek Te) 
in Cambodia.8 During TA inception, RAS guidelines will be developed to define objectives, 
process, requirements, and outputs. In the first stage, the RBOs in the pilot basins, with their 
own resources, will prepare or update a river basin profile in collaboration with stakeholders and 
the RAS guidelines. In the second stage, a small RAS team of international and national 
specialists  and  NARBO  peer  experts  will  visit  the  basin  to  conduct  a  river  basin  profile 
assessment to identify IWRM investment needs. This stage will end with a basin stakeholder 
workshop to discuss the assessment’s findings and develop a road map outline for a long-term 
integrated river basin investment program. In the third stage, the RBO will finalize the road map, 
and a second basin stakeholder workshop will be held to review it. The RAS team will provide

is a good example. It sets out a phased IWRM investment program over 15 years.  
8  RAS development will draw on ADB’s earlier work in defining IWRM elements and a generic road map for

further advice as needed in helping the RBO to finalize the road map, which will then serve as 
basis for future project preparatory TA for an investment project. 
 
15.  RBO Knowledge Service. Up-to-date information and knowledge will be compiled and 
provided to better equip RBOs in addressing changing river basin management needs for IWRM, 
including urbanization, decentralization, stakeholder collaboration, water rights and allocation, 
adaptation to climate change, and integrating environmental management in infrastructure and 
water  services  development.  Online  access and  dissemination  of  knowledge  products  and 
services will be improved through a regional knowledge hub under APWF.  
 
16.  Country Performance Assessments. Systematic country performance assessments 
will be conducted to chart the progress of introducing IWRM against monitorable indicators and 
to gather experience and lessons learned from basin projects implemented to date. These 
assessments will involve national water sector apex bodies, key water agencies, RBOs, and 
other stakeholders, and will result in specific recommendations for investment programs to 
address the changing needs in IWRM. Dialogues on assessment results will be held with 
stakeholders. The results will be disseminated in a publication that will highlight the region’s 
overall performance, challenges, lessons learned, and opportunities for basin water investments.  
 
17.  RBO Performance Improvement. Capacity development activities will be organized to 
improve RBO performance through diagnostic assessments, training programs, workshops, and 
seminars. These are expected to include: (i) training workshops for RBOs and stakeholders on 
preparing investment road maps with the RAS, (ii) peer reviewer certification training for senior 
RBO staff to conduct NARBO’s performance benchmarking service, (iii) leadership training for 
RBO champions in implementing IWRM and organizational changes, and (iv) seminars on 
adapting to the changing needs in IWRM and on improving water governance.9  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The total cost of the proposed TA is estimated at $2,000,000. The proposed TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The 
total cost of the project development facility (component 1) is estimated at about $1,000,000, of 
which the direct costs of the RAS pilot in the five basins are estimated at $600,000, or 30% of 
the overall TA cost.10 The cost estimates for components 2, 3, and 4 amount to $300,000, 
$400,000, and $300,000, respectively.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The proposed TA will be executed by ADB through the Energy, Transport, and Water 
Division of the Regional and Sustainable Development Department, in collaboration with the 
Basin Water Stream of ADB’s Water Community of Practice, concerned regional departments, 
and resident missions.  
 
20.  The organizational arrangements will include a TA team of specialists, which is expected 
to form part of the regional knowledge hub in Indonesia for river basin organizations and

management under APWF.11 Implementation of the project development facility for the pilot 
basins will also involve staff from the concerned RBOs, water agencies, and other government 
agencies  and  stakeholders  in  the  five  countries,  as  appropriate.  Senior  experts  from 
development partner organizations will be invited to advise key stages of TA implementation, 
especially during inception, RAS piloting, and TA workshops to review draft outputs. This TA 
advisory group is expected to include experts from the NARBO secretariat and knowledge 
partners, such as the Japan Water Agency, Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), 
IWMI, IUCN, APWF, and the Japan Water Forum (APWF’s secretariat). The organizational 
arrangements will be finalized during an inception workshop within the first three months of TA 
implementation. 
 
21.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 24 months, starting July 2008 and ending in 
June 2010.  
 
22.  ADB  will  engage  the  services  of  two  international  consultants  for  a  total  of  30  
person-months: (i) a senior IWRM specialist (24 person-months) as team leader, and (ii) a 
knowledge management specialist (6 person-months) for the publication and dissemination 
activities. ADB will also engage 11 national consultants for a total of 26 person-months: (i) a TA 
coordinator  (6  person-months)  at  ADB  headquarters  to  monitor  and  coordinate  the 
implementation  of  TA  activities  with  ADB’s  Water  Community  of  Practice  and  regional 
departments; and (ii) 10 project specialists (2 person-months each, with expertise in either water 
resources, environment, or governance, as needed) to support the RAS in the pilot basins. The 
method of consultant selection will be decided during implementation. All consultants will be 
engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 
3. Equipment and vehicles will be procured following ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time). It is expected that the TA team will use the vehicles at the regional 
knowledge hub, which will be turned over to the hub at TA completion.  
 
23.  The TA team of consultants will submit (i) an inception report at the end of the third 
month following mobilization; (ii) quarterly progress reports; (iii) an interim report at the end of 
the twelfth month; (iv) a draft final report at the end of the twenty-second month; and (v) a final 
report that incorporates comments by ADB, concerned RBOs, the TA advisory group, and 
stakeholders. Meetings between ADB and the TA team, including other concerned parties, will 
be held following report submission and as often as necessary. The TA’s outputs will be posted 
on ADB’s web site. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION  
 
24.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis for Managing Water in Asia’s River 
Basins: Charting Progress and Facilitating Investment.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be carried out over 24 months. The Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) will finance 56 person-months of consulting services, 30 international and 26 national. 
The consultants will work as a team under the overall leadership of the international integrated 
water resources management (IWRM) specialist. The team is expected to work in the regional 
knowledge hub. 
 
A.  Team Leader/IWRM Specialist (international, 24 person-months) 
2.  The consultant will have at least a Master’s degree in water resources management and 
over 10 years of experience following the IWRM approach in several countries. The consultant will 
lead  the  team  of  international  and  national  consultants  and  ensure  team  integration  through 
coordination  and  regular  meetings  with  team  members,  ADB,  government,  river  basin 
organizations (RBOs), and other stakeholders. The consultant will manage the relations and liaise 
with the TA advisory group and various organizations in the region; take overall responsibility for 
the quality, consistency, and timely delivery of all TA products in accordance with ADB's policies 
and standards; and manage the financial and technical aspects of TA operations. The consultant 
will have overall responsibility for the conduct of TA inception and completion workshops, basin 
stakeholder workshops, training seminars, dialogues, and other training activities. The consultant 
will carry out the following technical responsibilities for components 1, 3, and 4: 
 
1.  Component 1: Project Development Facility 
 
(i)  Develop  guidelines  for  the  road  map  advisory  service  (RAS)  to  elaborate  the 
objectives, process, requirements, and outputs.  
(ii)  Develop and pilot the RAS to help RBOs introduce or strengthen IWRM involving 
the following three-stage process: (a) assist five RBOs to prepare or update river 
basin profiles; (b) conduct an assessment of river basins, identifying investment 
needs for IWRM; and (c) finalize the road map for the investment program. 
 
2.  Component 3: Country Performance Assessments 
 
(i)  Conduct  systematic  country  performance  assessments  to  chart  the  progress  of 
introducing IWRM in river basins against monitorable indicators. 
(ii)  Gather experience and lessons learned from implemented basin projects. 
(iii)  Conduct dialogues on country and basin assessment results, and develop specific 
recommendations for action. 
(iv)  Analyze country action plans, and prepare a synthesis report that gives a regional 
overview of the status of IWRM in river basins.  
(v)  Facilitate regional knowledge sharing of the assessments and results. 
 
3.  Component 4: RBO Performance Improvement 
 
(i)  Assist in basin stakeholder workshops, training seminars, peer reviewer certification 
training, leadership training, and dialogues. 
(ii)  Facilitate the exchange of experiences among RBOs.

B.  Knowledge Management Specialist (international, 6 person-months) 
 
3.  The consultant will have expertise in knowledge management; public and media relations; 
multimedia production; information, education, and communication; and graphic design. In close 
collaboration with ADB’s Office of External Relations, and in regular consultation with ADB’s water 
community of practice, the consultant will be responsible for the outputs of components 2 and 3 as 
outlined below.  
 
1.  Component 2: RBO Knowledge Service 
 
(i)  Improve the online access and regional dissemination of existing IWRM publications, 
e.g.  ADB’s  Water  for  All  series,  World  Conservation  Union’s  publications,  and 
Global Water Partnership’s toolkit.  
(ii)  Improve online knowledge services for RBO practitioners and project staff, including 
the IWRM handbook, web sites/blogs, standard terms of reference for river basin 
assessments, guidelines and check lists for IWRM, one-page briefs, useful course 
materials including PowerPoint presentations, and good practice guides. 
(iii)  Undertake the following publications: (a) RAS guidelines, and (b) case studies on 
innovative approaches emerging from country and basin assessments.  
(iv)  Develop knowledge products on new basin challenges. 
 
2.  Component 3: Country Performance Assessments 
 
(i)  Undertake the publication of country action plans and the regional overview. 
(ii)  Disseminate the action plan to policymakers in government and civil society at the 
regional level.  
 
C.  TA Coordinator (national, 6 person-months)  
 
4.  The consultant will monitor and coordinate the implementation of TA activities with ADB’s 
Water Community of Practice and regional departments and will be based at ADB headquarters. 
 
D.  Project Specialists (national, 10 persons for 2 person-months each)  
5.  The consultants will assist the team leader in piloting the RAS in five river basins. The 
consultants will provide expertise in the fields of water resources management, environment, or 
governance, in accordance with specific river basin needs.
